translated: When there is devotion to desirable actions and fame among embodied beings,

analyzed: tadā tretā rajaḥ vṛttiḥ iti jānīhi buddhiman
translated: then know that to be the Treta age, O wise one, when rajas predominates.

original: yadā lobhas tv asantoṣo māno dambho 'tha matsaraḥ
analyzed: yadā lobhaḥ tu asantoṣaḥ mānaḥ matsaraḥ
translated: When there is greed, discontent, pride, hypocrisy, and envy,

original: karmaṇāṃ cāpi kāmyānāṃ dvāparaṃ tad rajastamaḥ🔽yadā māyānṛtaṃ tandrā nidrā hiṃsā viṣādanam
analyzed: karmaṇām ca api kāmyānām dvāparam tat rajaḥ tamaḥ  yadā māyā anṛtam tandrā nidrā hiṃsā viṣādanam
translated: and also for desirable actions, that is Dvapara, a mixture of rajas and tamas.🔽When there is illusion, falsehood, laziness, sleep, violence, dejection,

analyzed: śoka mohau bhayam dainyam sa kaliḥ tāmasaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: grief, delusion, fear, and despondency, that is Kali, known as the age of tamas.

analyzed: tasmāt kṣudra dṛśaḥ martyāḥ kṣudra bhāgyāḥ mahā aśanāḥ
translated: Therefore, men of petty vision, of petty luck, and of great appetite,

original: kāmino vittahīnāś ca svairiṇyaś ca striyo 'satīḥ
analyzed: kāminaḥ vitta hīnāḥ ca svairiṇyaḥ ca striyaḥ satīḥ
translated: passionate, poor in wealth, and unchaste women who stray,

analyzed: dasyu utkṛṣṭāḥ janapadāḥ vedāḥ pāṣaṇḍa dūṣitāḥ
translated: countries ruled by bandits, Vedas defiled by heresy,

original: rājānaś ca prajābhakṣāḥ śiśnodaraparā dvijāḥ🔽avratā baṭavo 'śaucā bhikṣavaś ca kuṭumbinaḥ
analyzed: rājānaḥ ca prajā bhakṣāḥ śiśna udara parāḥ dvijāḥ  avratāḥ śaucāḥ bhikṣavaḥ ca kuṭumbinaḥ
translated: kings who devour their subjects, Brahmins intent on penis and belly,🔽uninitiated boys without vows, impure ascetics, and householding monks,

original: tapasvino grāmavāsā nyāsino 'tyarthalolupāḥ🔽hrasvakāyā mahāhārā bhūryapatyā gatahriyaḥ🔽śaśvat kaṭukabhāṣiṇyaś cauryamāyorusāhasāḥ
analyzed: tapasvinaḥ grāma vāsāḥ tyartha lolupāḥ  hrasva kāyāḥ mahā āhārāḥ bhūri apatyāḥ gata hriyaḥ  śaśvat kaṭuka bhāṣiṇyaḥ caurya māyā uru sāhasāḥ
translated: ascetics living in villages, renunciates extremely greedy,🔽with short bodies and large appetites, many children and lost shame,🔽always speaking harshly, with great enthusiasm for theft and deceit,

analyzed: paṇayiṣyanti vai kṣudrāḥ kirāṭāḥ kūṭa kāriṇaḥ
translated: lowly traders, hunters, and cheats will sell,

original: anāpady api maṃsyante vārtāṃ sādhu jugupsitām🔽patiṃ tyakṣyanti nirdravyaṃ bhṛtyā apy akhilottamam
analyzed: anāpadi api maṃsyante vārtām sādhu jugupsitām  patim tyakṣyanti nirdravyam bhṛtyāḥ api akhila uttamam
translated: they will consider a despicable livelihood even in times of no difficulty,🔽they will abandon their husband who is destitute, even servants, the best of all,

original: bhṛtyaṃ vipannaṃ patayaḥ kaulaṃ gāś cāpayasvinīḥ
analyzed: bhṛtyam vipannam patayaḥ kaulam gāḥ ca a payasvinīḥ
translated: masters will abandon a servant who has fallen, and cows a bull that is weak,

analyzed: pitṛ bhrātṛ suhṛd jñātīn hitvā saurata sauhṛdāḥ
translated: abandoning fathers, brothers, friends, and relatives, with love only for sexual pleasure,

analyzed: dīnāḥ straiṇāḥ kalau narāḥ
translated: in the Kali age men will be miserable, dependent on women, with false promises to their mothers-in-law,

analyzed: śūdrāḥ pratigrahīṣyanti tapaḥ veṣa upajīvinaḥ
translated: Shudras will accept gifts, living off the guise of ascetics,

analyzed: dharmam vakṣyanti a dharma jñāḥ adhiruhya uttama āsanam
translated: They will expound dharma, though ignorant of dharma, from exalted seats.

analyzed: nityam udvigna manasaḥ durbhikṣa kara karśitāḥ
translated: Always anxious, afflicted by famine and drought,

analyzed: niranne bhū tale rājan anāvṛṣṭi bhaya āturāḥ  vāsa unna pāna śayana vyavāya snāna bhūṣaṇaiḥ
translated: with the earth devoid of food, O king, terrified by the fear of drought,🔽deprived of clothing, food, drink, bedding, sexual intercourse, bathing, and ornaments,

analyzed: hīnāḥ piśāca sandarśāḥ bhaviṣyanti kalau prajāḥ
translated: the people will resemble demons in Kali Yuga.

analyzed: kalau kākiṇike pi arthe vigṛhya tyakta sauhṛdāḥ
translated: In Kali Yuga, even for the sake of a small amount of money, they will quarrel, abandon affection,

original: tyakṣyanti ca priyān prāṇān haniṣyanti svakān api
analyzed: tyakṣyanti ca priyān prāṇān haniṣyanti svakān api
translated: give up their dear lives, and even kill their own people.

original: na rakṣiṣyanti manujāḥ sthavirau pitarāv api
analyzed: na rakṣiṣyanti manujāḥ sthavirau pitarau api
translated: Men will not protect even their aged parents,

original: putrān bhāryāṃ ca kulajāṃ kṣudrāḥ śiśnodaraṃbharāḥ
analyzed: putrān bhāryām ca kula jām kṣudrāḥ śiśna udaraṃbharāḥ
translated: the low ones, burdened by the penis and belly, will abandon their sons and wives born in noble families.

original: kalau na rājan jagatāṃ paraṃ guruṃ trilokanāthānatapādapaṅkajam🔽prāyeṇa martyā bhagavantam acyutaṃ yakṣyanti pāṣaṇḍavibhinnacetasaḥ
analyzed: kalau na rājan jagatām param gurum triloka nātha ānata pāda paṅkajam  prāyeṇa martyāḥ bhagavantam acyutam yakṣyanti pāṣaṇḍa vibhinna cetasaḥ
translated: O king, in Kali Yuga, people will not worship the Supreme Guru of the worlds, the lotus feet of the Lord of the three worlds,🔽who is bowed to by the world, with a mind divided by heresy.

original: yannāmadheyaṃ mriyamāṇa āturaḥ patan skhalan vā vivaśo gṛṇan pumān
analyzed: yad nāmadheyam mriyamāṇaḥ āturaḥ patan skhalan vā vivaśaḥ gṛṇan pumān
translated: A man, helplessly uttering the name of that Lord, when dying, sick, falling, or stumbling,

original: vimuktakarmārgala uttamāṃ gatiṃ prāpnoti yakṣyanti na taṃ kalau janāḥ
analyzed: vimukta karma argalaḥ uttamām gatim prāpnoti yakṣyanti na tam kalau janāḥ
translated: is freed from the shackles of karma and attains the highest state. People will not worship Him in Kali Yuga.

analyzed: puṃsām kali kṛtān doṣān dravya deśa ātma sambhavān
translated: The faults arising from the body, place, and self of men in the Kali age,

analyzed: sarvān harati citta sthaḥ bhagavān puruṣottamaḥ
translated: The Supreme Personality of Godhead, residing in the heart, removes all the faults of men born of the age of quarrel, faults arising from material objects, places and the self.

original: śrutaḥ saṅkīrtito dhyātaḥ pūjitaś cādṛto 'pi vā
analyzed: śrutaḥ saṅkīrtitaḥ dhyātaḥ pūjitaḥ vā
translated: Whether heard, chanted, meditated upon, worshipped or even disrespected,

analyzed: nṛṇām dhunoti bhagavān hṛd sthaḥ janma ayuta aśubham
translated: the Supreme Lord, residing in the heart, removes the inauspiciousness accumulated in ten thousand births of men.

original: yathā hemni sthito vahnir durvarṇaṃ hanti dhātujam
analyzed: yathā hemni sthitaḥ vahniḥ durvarṇam hanti dhātu jam
translated: Just as fire residing in gold removes the discoloration caused by metals,

analyzed: evam ātma gataḥ viṣṇuḥ yoginām aśubha āśayam
translated: in the same way, Lord Vishnu residing in the self removes the inauspicious thoughts of yogis.

analyzed: vidyā tapaḥ prāṇa nirodha maitrī tīrtha abhiṣeka vrata dāna japyaiḥ
translated: By knowledge, austerity, control of life airs, friendliness, bathing in holy places, vows, charity and japa,

original: nātyantaśuddhiṃ labhate 'ntarātmā yathā hṛdisthe bhagavaty anante
analyzed: na atyanta śuddhim labhate ntarātmā yathā hṛdisthe bhagavati anante
translated: the inner self does not attain absolute purity as when the infinite Lord resides in the heart.

original: tasmāt sarvātmanā rājan hṛdisthaṃ kuru keśavam
analyzed: tasmāt sarva ātmanā rājan hṛdistham kuru keśavam
translated: Therefore, O king, with all your heart, keep Keshava in your heart.

original: mriyamāṇo hy avahitas tato yāsi parāṃ gatim
analyzed: mriyamāṇaḥ hi avahitaḥ tatas yāsi parām gatim
translated: For when you die, absorbed in Him, you will attain the supreme destination.

analyzed: mriyamāṇaiḥ abhidhyeyaḥ bhagavān parameśvaraḥ
translated: The Supreme Lord should be meditated upon by those who are dying.

analyzed: ātma bhāvam nayati aṅga sarva ātmā sarva saṃśrayaḥ
translated: O limb, the all-pervading, all-supporting Lord leads one to His own abode.

original: kaler doṣanidhe rājann asti hy eko mahān guṇaḥ
analyzed: kaleḥ doṣa nidhe rājan asti hi ekaḥ mahān guṇaḥ
translated: O king, in the ocean of faults that is the age of quarrel, there is one great virtue:

original: kīrtanād eva kṛṣṇasya muktasaṅgaḥ paraṃ vrajet
analyzed: kīrtanāt eva kṛṣṇasya mukta saṅgaḥ param vrajet
translated: By simply chanting the name of Krishna, one becomes detached and attains the supreme destination.

original: kṛte yad dhyāyato viṣṇuṃ tretāyāṃ yajato makhaiḥ
analyzed: kṛte yat dhyāyataḥ viṣṇum tretāyām yajataḥ makhaiḥ
translated: What is attained by meditating on Vishnu in Kṛta Yuga, by performing sacrifices in Tretā Yuga,

analyzed: dvāpare paricaryāyām kalau tat hari kīrtanāt
translated: by rendering service in Dvāpara Yuga, that is attained by chanting the glories of Lord Hari in Kali Yuga.

analyzed: śrī śukaḥ uvāca
translated: Śrī Śuka said:

analyzed: kālaḥ te paramāṇu ādiḥ dvi parārdha avadhiḥ nṛpa
translated: O King, the time from the smallest unit to two Parārdhas has been told to you.

original: kathito yugamānaṃ ca śṛṇu kalpalayāv api
analyzed: kathitaḥ yuga mānam ca śṛṇu kalpa layau api
translated: Listen also to the measure of the Yugas and the dissolution of the Kalpa.

analyzed: catur yuga sahasram tu brahmaṇaḥ dinam ucyate
translated: One thousand sets of four Yugas are said to be one day of Brahmā.

original: sa kalpo yatra manavaś caturdaśa viśāmpate
analyzed: sa kalpaḥ yatra manavaḥ caturdaśa viśām pate
translated: O lord of the people, that is one Kalpa in which there are fourteen Manus.

original: tadante pralayas tāvān brāhmī rātrir udāhṛtā
analyzed: tad ante pralayaḥ tāvān brāhmī rātriḥ udāhṛtā
translated: At the end of that, there is a dissolution of the same duration, which is said to be Brahmā's night.

original: trayo lokā ime tatra kalpante pralayāya hi
analyzed: trayaḥ lokāḥ ime tatra kalpante pralayāya hi
translated: These three worlds there dissolve for the sake of dissolution.

original: eṣa naimittikaḥ proktaḥ pralayo yatra viśvasṛk
analyzed: eṣa naimittikaḥ proktaḥ pralayaḥ yatra viśvasṛj
translated: This is said to be the occasional dissolution, where the creator of the universe

analyzed: śete nanta āsanaḥ viśvam ātmasāt kṛtya ca ātmabhūḥ
translated: lies down on Ananta's abode, having absorbed the universe into Himself, the Self-existent One.

analyzed: dvi parārdhe tu atikrānte brahmaṇaḥ parameṣṭhinaḥ
translated: When two Parārdhas have passed of Brahmā, the Supreme Lord,

original: tadā prakṛtayaḥ sapta kalpante pralayāya vai
analyzed: tadā prakṛtayaḥ sapta kalpante pralayāya vai
translated: then the seven primordial elements dissolve for the sake of dissolution.

original: eṣa prākṛtiko rājan pralayo yatra līyate
analyzed: eṣa prākṛtikaḥ rājan pralayaḥ yatra līyate
translated: This, O king, is the natural dissolution, where the universe dissolves.

analyzed: aṇḍakoṣaḥ tu saṅghātaḥ vighāṭaḥ upasādite
translated: But the egg-shell, the aggregate, is destroyed when the dissolution is imminent.

original: parjanyaḥ śatavarṣāṇi bhūmau rājan na varṣati
analyzed: parjanyaḥ śata varṣāṇi bhūmau rājan na varṣati
translated: O king, Parjanya does not rain on the earth for a hundred years.

original: tadā niranne hy anyonyaṃ bhakṣyamāṇāḥ kṣudhārditāḥ
analyzed: tadā niranne hi anyonyam bhakṣyamāṇāḥ kṣudhā arditāḥ
translated: Then, when there is no food, afflicted by hunger, they will eat each other.

original: kṣayaṃ yāsyanti śanakaiḥ kālenopadrutāḥ prajāḥ🔽sāmudraṃ daihikaṃ bhaumaṃ rasaṃ sāṃvartako raviḥ
analyzed: kṣayam yāsyanti śanakais kālena upadrutāḥ prajāḥ  sāmudram daihikam bhaumam rasam sāṃvartakaḥ raviḥ
translated: Afflicted by time, the people will gradually perish.🔽The sun, which brings about dissolution, with its terrible rays, drinks up the water of the ocean, the body, and the earth.

original: raśmibhiḥ pibate ghoraiḥ sarvaṃ naiva vimuñcati
analyzed: raśmibhiḥ pibate ghoraiḥ sarvam na eva vimuñcati
translated: It does not release anything.

analyzed: tatas saṃvartakaḥ vahniḥ saṅkarṣaṇa mukha utthitaḥ
translated: Then the fire of dissolution, arisen from the mouth of Saṅkarṣaṇa,

analyzed: dahati anila vega utthaḥ śūnyān bhū vivarān atha
translated: is fanned by the speed of the wind and burns the empty spaces and cavities of the earth.

original: upary adhaḥ samantāc ca śikhābhir vahnisūryayoḥ
analyzed: upari adhas samantāt ca śikhābhiḥ vahni sūryayoḥ
translated: Above, below, and all around, by the flames of fire and the sun,

analyzed: dahyamānam vibhāti aṇḍam dagdha gomaya piṇḍa vat
translated: the universe appears to be burning, like a lump of burnt cow dung.

analyzed: tatas pracaṇḍa pavanaḥ varṣāṇām adhikam śatam
translated: Then, for more than a hundred years, a fierce wind blows.

original: paraḥ sāṃvartako vāti dhūmraṃ khaṃ rajasāvṛtam
analyzed: paraḥ sāṃvartakaḥ vāti dhūmram kham rajasā āvṛtam
translated: The sky becomes smoky and covered with dust.

original: tato meghakulāny aṅga citra varṇāny anekaśaḥ
analyzed: tatas megha kulāni aṅga citra varṇāni anekaśas
translated: Then, O child, there appear many multi-colored clouds

analyzed: śatam varṣāṇi varṣanti nadanti rabhasa svanaiḥ
translated: and for a hundred years they rain and thunder with loud sounds.

analyzed: tatas ekodakam viśvam
translated: Then the entire universe becomes one vast expanse of water,

original: brahmāṇḍavivarāntaram🔽tadā bhūmer gandhaguṇaṃ grasanty āpa udaplave
analyzed: tadā bhūmeḥ gandha guṇam grasanti āpaḥ uda plave
translated: from the surface of the earth up to the end of the universe.🔽Then the water devours the quality of smell of the earth during the flood.

analyzed: grasta gandhā tu pṛthivī pralaya tvāya kalpate
translated: When the earth loses its smell, it is ready for dissolution.

original: apāṃ rasam atho tejas tā līyante 'tha nīrasāḥ🔽grasate tejaso rūpaṃ vāyus tadrahitaṃ tadā
analyzed: apām rasam atha u tejaḥ tāḥ līyante nīrasāḥ  grasate tejasaḥ rūpam vāyuḥ tad rahitam tadā
translated: The water then absorbs the essence of the water and the energy, and becomes tasteless.🔽Then the wind absorbs the form of the energy, and it becomes devoid of that.

original: līyate cānile tejo vāyoḥ khaṃ grasate guṇam
analyzed: līyate ca anile tejaḥ vāyoḥ kham grasate guṇam
translated: The energy of the wind then dissolves into the wind, and the wind absorbs the quality of space.

original: sa vai viśati khaṃ rājaṃs tataś ca nabhaso guṇam
analyzed: sa vai viśati kham rājan tatas ca nabhasaḥ guṇam
translated: Then, O king, it enters into space, and the quality of space

original: śabdaṃ grasati bhūtādir nabhas tam anu līyate
analyzed: śabdam grasati bhūtādiḥ nabhaḥ tam anu līyate
translated: is absorbed by the primordial element, and space dissolves into it.

original: taijasaś cendriyāṇy aṅga devān vaikāriko guṇaiḥ
analyzed: taijasaḥ ca indriyāṇi aṅga devān vaikārikaḥ guṇaiḥ
translated: The element of energy, O limb, absorbs the senses, and the modified ego absorbs the gods with their qualities.

original: mahān grasaty ahaṅkāraṃ guṇāḥ sattvādayaś ca tam
analyzed: mahān grasati ahaṅkāram guṇāḥ sattva ādayaḥ ca tam
translated: The great one absorbs the ego, and the qualities such as goodness absorb it.

analyzed: grasate vyākṛtam rājan guṇān kālena coditam
translated: The unmanifest absorbs them, O king, impelled by time.

analyzed: na tasya kāla avayavaiḥ pariṇāma ādayaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: It has no qualities such as transformation due to the parts of time.

original: anādy anantam avyaktaṃ nityaṃ kāraṇam avyayam
analyzed: anādi anantam avyaktam nityam kāraṇam avyayam
translated: It is beginningless, endless, unmanifest, eternal, the cause, and immutable.

original: na yatra vāco na mano na sattvaṃ tamo rajo vā mahadādayo 'mī
analyzed: na yatra vācaḥ na manaḥ na sattvam tamaḥ rajaḥ vā mahat ādayaḥ
translated: Where there are no words, no mind, no existence, no darkness, no passion, and these great elements,

original: na prāṇabuddhīndriyadevatā vā na sanniveśaḥ khalu lokakalpaḥ
analyzed: na prāṇa buddhīndriya devatāḥ vā na sanniveśaḥ khalu loka kalpaḥ
translated: No vital airs, no intellect, no senses, no deities, no arrangement, no creation of the world,

original: na svapnajāgran na ca tat suṣuptaṃ na khaṃ jalaṃ bhūr anilo 'gnir arkaḥ
analyzed: na svapna jāgrat na ca tat suṣuptam na kham jalam bhūḥ anilaḥ gniḥ arkaḥ
translated: No dream, no waking, no deep sleep, no space, no water, no earth, no air, no fire, no sun,

original: saṃsuptavac chūnyavad apratarkyaṃ tan mūlabhūtaṃ padam āmananti
analyzed: saṃsupta vat śūnya vat apratarkyam tat mūla bhūtam padam āmananti
translated: That is said to be the primordial state, like one who is asleep, like one who is empty, and is beyond thought.

original: layaḥ prākṛtiko hy eṣa puruṣāvyaktayor yadā
analyzed: layaḥ prākṛtikaḥ hi eṣa puruṣa avyaktayoḥ yadā
translated: This is the natural dissolution of the Purusha and the unmanifest,

analyzed: śaktayaḥ sampralīyante vivaśāḥ kāla vidrutāḥ
translated: when the powers, being powerless, dissolve due to the destruction of time.

original: buddhīndriyārtharūpeṇa jñānaṃ bhāti tadāśrayam🔽dṛśyatvāvyatirekābhyām ādyantavad avastu yat
analyzed: buddhīndriya artha rūpeṇa jñānam bhāti tad āśrayam  dṛśya tva avyatirekābhyām ādi anta vat avastu yat
translated: Knowledge shines as the object of the senses and the intellect, having that as its basis.🔽That which is not different from the visible and has a beginning and an end is unreal.

original: dīpaś cakṣuś ca rūpaṃ ca jyotiṣo na pṛthag bhavet
analyzed: dīpaḥ cakṣuḥ ca rūpam ca jyotiṣaḥ na pṛthak bhavet
translated: The lamp, the eye, and form would not be different from light.

original: evaṃ dhīḥ khāni mātrāś ca na syur anyatamād ṛtāt
analyzed: evam dhīḥ khāni mātrāḥ ca na syuḥ anyatamāt ṛtāt
translated: In the same way, the intellect, the senses, and the objects would not be different from the truth.

original: buddher jāgaraṇaṃ svapnaḥ suṣuptir iti cocyate
analyzed: buddheḥ jāgaraṇam svapnaḥ suṣuptiḥ iti ca ucyate
translated: It is said to be waking, dreaming, and deep sleep.

analyzed: māyā mātram idam rājan nānātvam pratyagātmani
translated: O king, this diversity in the inner self is mere illusion.

original: yathā jaladharā vyomni bhavanti na bhavanti ca
analyzed: yathā jaladharāḥ vyomni bhavanti na bhavanti ca
translated: Just as clouds exist and do not exist in the sky,

analyzed: brahmaṇi idam tathā viśvam avayavi udaya apyayāt
translated: in the same way this universe exists and does not exist in Brahman, due to the arising and dissolution of the whole.

original: satyaṃ hy avayavaḥ proktaḥ sarvāvayavinām iha
analyzed: satyam hi avayavaḥ proktaḥ sarva avayavinām iha
translated: The truth is said to be the part of all wholes here.

analyzed: vinā arthena pratīyeran paṭasya iva aṅga tantavaḥ
translated: They would be known without meaning, like the threads of a cloth.

analyzed: yat sāmānya viśeṣābhyām upalabhyeta sa bhramaḥ
translated: That which is perceived by the universal and the particular is an illusion.

original: anyonyāpāśrayāt sarvam ādyantavad avastu yat🔽vikāraḥ khyāyamāno 'pi pratyagātmānam antarā
analyzed: anyonya apāśrayāt sarvam ādi antavat avastu yat  vikāraḥ khyāyamānaḥ pi pratyagātmānam antarā
translated: Everything is without substance, having a beginning and an end, because it is mutually dependent.🔽Even when change appears, it is not to be conceived apart from the inner self.

original: na nirūpyo 'sty aṇur api syāc cec citsama ātmavat
analyzed: na nirūpyaḥ sti aṇuḥ api syāt ced cit samaḥ ātma vat
translated: If it were, not even an atom could be conceived, for then it would be like the self.

original: na hi satyasya nānātvam avidvān yadi manyate
analyzed: na hi satyasya nānātvam a vidvān yadi manyate

analyzed: yathā hiraṇyam bahudhā samīyate nṛbhiḥ kriyābhiḥ vyavahāra vartmasu

analyzed: yathā ghanaḥ rka prabhavaḥ rka darśitaḥ

translated: and the darkness of the eye, which is a part of the sun,

analyzed: evam tu aham brahma guṇaḥ tad īkṣitaḥ
translated: in the same way, I am a quality of Brahman, seen by Him,

analyzed: brahma aṃśakasya ātmanaḥ ātma bandhanaḥ

analyzed: ghanaḥ yadā arka prabhavaḥ vidīryate cakṣuḥ sva rūpam ravim īkṣate tadā
translated: When the cloud, born from the sun, is dispersed, then the eye sees its own form, the sun.

analyzed: yadā hi ahaṅkāraḥ upādhiḥ ātmanaḥ jijñāsayā naśyati tarhi anusmaret
translated: When the limiting adjunct of the self, the sense of I, is destroyed by inquiry, then one would remember.

analyzed: yadā evam etena viveka hetinā māyā maya ahaṅkaraṇa ātma bandhanam
translated: When, by this weapon of discrimination, one cuts the bonds of the ego and the sense organs, which are made of illusion,

original: chittvācyutātmānubhavo 'vatiṣṭhate tam āhur ātyantikam aṅga samplavam
analyzed: chittvā acyuta ātma anubhavaḥ vatiṣṭhate tam āhuḥ ātyantikam aṅga samplavam
translated: and abides in the experience of the unchanging Self, then, O limb, they call it the ultimate dissolution.

analyzed: nityadā sarva bhūtānām brahma ādīnām parantapa
translated: O scorcher of enemies, for all beings, beginning with Brahma,

analyzed: utpatti pralayau eke sūkṣma jñāḥ sampracakṣate
translated: some subtle knowers describe the creation and dissolution as occurring all the time.

analyzed: kāla srotaḥ javena āśu hriyamāṇasya nityadā
translated: As time swiftly carries everything away in the current of its flow,

analyzed: anādi antavatā anena kālena īśvara mūrtinā
translated: By this time, which has no beginning or end, in the form of the Lord,

translated: the states are not seen, as if in the sky of the stars.

analyzed: nityaḥ naimittikaḥ ca eva tathā prākṛtikaḥ layaḥ  ātyantikaḥ ca kathitaḥ kālasya gatiḥ īdṛśī
translated: The natural dissolution, the occasional dissolution, and the ultimate dissolution,🔽such is the course of time.

translated: O best of the Kurus, these stories of the pastimes of the creator of the world, Narayana, the abode of all existence,

analyzed: līlā kathāḥ te kathitāḥ samāsatas kārtsnyena na ajaḥ pi abhidhātum īśaḥ
translated: have been told to you in brief. Even the unborn Brahma is not able to describe them in their entirety.

analyzed: saṃsāra sindhum ati dustaram uttitīrṣoḥ
translated: For one who desires to cross the ocean of worldly existence, which is very difficult to cross,

analyzed: līlā kathā rasa niṣevaṇam antareṇa
translated: Without resorting to the nectar of playful stories,

analyzed: puṃsaḥ bhavet vividha duḥkha dava arditasya
translated: a person afflicted by the forest fire of various miseries

analyzed: purāṇa saṃhitām etām ṛṣiḥ nārāyaṇaḥ vyayaḥ
translated: The immutable sage Narayana formerly narrated this collection of Puranas

analyzed: nāradāya purā prāha kṛṣṇadvaipāyanāya saḥ
translated: to Narada and then Krishna Dvaipayana.

analyzed: sa vai mahyam mahā rāja bhagavān bādarāyaṇaḥ

analyzed: imām bhāgavatīm prītaḥ saṃhitām veda sammitām
translated: being pleased, narrated this Bhagavata Samhita, equal to the Vedas, to me.

original: imāṃ vakṣyaty asau sūta ṛṣibhyo naimiṣālaye
analyzed: imām vakṣyati asau sūtaḥ ṛṣibhyaḥ naimiṣa ālaye

translated: In this (Bhagavata), Hari, the soul of the universe, is frequently described,

analyzed: yasya prasāda jaḥ brahmā rudraḥ krodha samudbhavaḥ

translated: You will not become non-existent after becoming one endowed with the form of son, grandson, etc.🔽Like the seed and sprout, you are distinct from the body etc., just as fire (is distinct from fuel).

original: svapne yathā śiraśchedaṃ pañcatvādy ātmanaḥ svayam
analyzed: svapne yathā śiraḥ chedam pañcatva ādi ātmanaḥ svayam
translated: As in a dream, one's own head being cut off, or death, etc.

analyzed: yasmāt paśyati dehasya tatas ātmā hi ajaḥ maraḥ
translated: Since the unborn and immortal Self is seen in the body,

analyzed: ghaṭe bhinne ghaṭa ākāśe ākāśaḥ syāt yathā purā
translated: just as when a pot is broken, the space in the pot becomes the same as the original space,

original: evaṃ dehe mṛte jīvo brahma sampadyate punaḥ
analyzed: evam dehe mṛte jīvaḥ brahma sampadyate punar
translated: in the same way, when the body dies, the individual soul merges again with Brahman.

analyzed: manaḥ sṛjati vai dehān guṇān karmāṇi ca ātmanaḥ
translated: The mind creates the bodies, qualities, and actions of the self.

original: tan manaḥ sṛjate māyā tato jīvasya saṃsṛtiḥ
analyzed: tat manaḥ sṛjate māyā tatas jīvasya saṃsṛtiḥ
translated: That mind creates illusion, and from that comes the transmigration of the individual soul.

analyzed: sneha adhiṣṭhāna varti agni saṃyogaḥ yāvat īyate
translated: As long as there is a union of the wick and fire in the base of oil,

analyzed: tāvat dīpasya dīpa tvam evam deha kṛtaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: for that long there is the light of the lamp; in the same way, the existence of the body is created.

analyzed: rajaḥ sattva tamaḥ vṛttyā jāyate vinaśyati
translated: It is born and destroyed by the fluctuations of rajas, sattva, and tamas.

original: na tatrātmā svayaṃjyotir yo vyaktāvyaktayoḥ paraḥ
analyzed: na tatra ātmā svayam jyotiḥ yaḥ vyakta avyaktayoḥ paraḥ

translated: And like space, it is the support, fixed and infinite.

analyzed: evam ātmānam ātma stham ātmanā eva āmṛśa prabho
translated: Thus, O Lord, touch the Self that is in the Self by the Self itself,

analyzed: buddhyā anumāna garbhiṇyā vāsudeva anucintayā

analyzed: mṛtyavaḥ na upadhakṣyanti mṛtyūnām mṛtyum īśvaram
translated: The messengers of death will not burn you, for you are the Lord of death, beyond death.

original: ahaṃ brahma paraṃ dhāma brahmāhaṃ paramaṃ padam
analyzed: aham brahma param dhāma brahma aham paramam padam
translated: I am Brahman, the supreme abode; Brahman is I, the supreme state.

analyzed: na drakṣyasi śarīram ca viśvam ca pṛthak ātmanaḥ
translated: You will not see the body or the universe separate from the Self,🔽Even though Takshaka is biting your foot and licking it with his poisonous mouths.

analyzed: etat te kathitam tāta yat ātmā pṛṣṭavān nṛpa
translated: O son, I have thus told you what the Self asked the king.

analyzed: hareḥ viśvātmanaḥ ceṣṭām kim bhūyas śrotum icchasi
translated: What more do you wish to hear about the activities of Hari, the Self of the universe?

translated: Suta said:

analyzed: vyāsa ātmajena nikhila ātma dṛśā samena  tad pāda mūlam upasṛtya natena mūrdhnā
translated: Parikshit, with a vision of the entire Self,🔽Approaching the foot of that (sage), with his head bowed and palms joined,

analyzed: baddhāñjaliḥ tam idam āha sa viṣṇurātaḥ
translated: Vishnu-rata spoke this to him.

translated: I am satisfied, I am favored by you, who are full of compassion,

translated: I do not consider it very wonderful for great souls whose minds are fixed on the infallible one,

translated: That they should show favor to ignorant beings tormented by suffering.

analyzed: purāṇa saṃhitām etām aśrauṣma bhavataḥ vayam
translated: We have heard this compendium of Puranas from you,

analyzed: yasyām khalu uttamaḥ ślokaḥ bhagavān

analyzed: bhagavan takṣaka ādibhyaḥ mṛtyubhyaḥ na bibhemi aham
translated: O Lord, I do not fear death from Takshaka and others,

analyzed: praviṣṭaḥ brahma nirvāṇam abhayam darśitam tvayā
translated: Having entered Brahman, the fearlessness shown by you, O Brahman,

analyzed: anujānīhi mām brahman vācam yacchāmi adhokṣaje

analyzed: ajñānam ca nirastam me jñāna vijñāna niṣṭhayā

analyzed: bhavatā darśitam kṣemam param bhagavataḥ padam

translated: Suta said:

translated: The body of the royal sage, who was absorbed in Brahman,

analyzed: tam gopāyati rāja indra śakraḥ śaraṇam āgatam

translated: Hearing Parikshit, the magnanimous one said to the priests:

translated: The subduing of the serpent Kaliya, the liberation of the great serpent, and of Nanda,

translated: The yawning of Hara in the battle, and the cutting off of the arms of Bana,

Shambara, Dvivida, Pitha, Mura, Panchajana and others,

analyzed: vipra śāpa apadeśena saṃhāraḥ sva kulasya ca

translated: Where the entire knowledge of the Self and the determination of Dharma are stated,

translated: Then the renunciation of the mortal body by the power of self-realization,

translated: The characteristics of the yugas and the calamities of men in the Kali Yuga,

analyzed: caturvidhaḥ ca pralayaḥ utpattiḥ trividhā tathā
translated: The four kinds of dissolution and the three kinds of creation,

translated: And the renunciation of the body by the wise royal sage Yudhishthira, son of Vichitravirya,

translated: One who has fallen, stumbled, become afflicted, hungry, or helpless, if he chants loudly,

translated: When the infinite Lord is glorified, His glory being heard, it removes the distress of men,

translated: That alone is delightful, charming, ever new, that alone is the great festival for the mind.

analyzed: tat dhvāṅkṣatīṛtham na tu haṃsa sevitam
translated: which does not proclaim the world-purifying glory of Hari.

analyzed: yatra acyutaḥ tatra hi sādhavaḥ malāḥ

analyzed: na śobhate jñānam alam nirañjanam

translated: How much less so is there constant misfortune for the Lord,

translated: It brings about the purification of sattva, devotion to the Supreme Self, knowledge endowed with wisdom and detachment.

original: yūyaṃ dvijāgryā bata bhūribhāgā yac chaśvad ātmany akhilātmabhūtam
analyzed: yūyam dvijāgryāḥ bata bhūri bhāgāḥ yat śaśvat ātmani akhilātma bhūtam

translated: Narayana, the God, the non-God, the Lord, who is the soul of all in the self.

translated: He who listens with undivided attention to this account of the Lord, even for a moment,

translated: In Pushkara, Mathura, and Dvaravati, one who controls oneself,

translated: Having studied this compendium of Puranas, a pure twice-born

analyzed: proktam bhagavatā yat tu tat padam paramam vrajet

translated: A Brahmin would attain wisdom, a Kshatriya would conquer the earth up to the ocean,

analyzed: iha tu punar bhagavān aśeṣa mūrtiḥ paripaṭhitaḥ nupadam kathā prasaṅgaiḥ
translated: but here, in this Purana, the Lord, in His entirety, is repeatedly mentioned in the course of the stories.

original: tam aham ajam anantam ātmatattvaṃ jagadudayasthitisaṃyamātmaśaktim
analyzed: tam aham ajam anantam ātma tattvam jagat udaya sthiti saṃyama ātma śaktim
translated: I bow to that unborn, infinite, true Self, whose power of creation, preservation, and dissolution is the origin, existence, and dissolution of the universe,

analyzed: dyupatibhiḥ aja śakra śaṅkara ādyaiḥ duravasita stavam acyutam nataḥ smi
translated: to that Acyuta, whose praise by the lords of heaven, Brahma, Indra, Shiva, and others, is beyond comprehension, I bow.

analyzed: upacita nava śaktibhiḥ sve ātmani uparacita sthira jaṅgama ālayāya
translated: To Him, who has created in His own Self the abode of the moving and unmoving world with His newly accumulated powers,

analyzed: bhagavataḥ upalabdhi mātra dhamne sura ṛṣabhāya namaḥ sanātanāya
translated: Salutations to the eternal bull among the gods, whose nature is known only through faith, to the Lord.

analyzed: sva sukha nibhṛta cetāḥ tad vyudasta anya bhāvaḥ
translated: With a mind absorbed in His bliss, devoid of all else,

analyzed: pi ajita rucira līlā ākṛṣṭa sāraḥ tadīyam
translated: and the essence of the swans is drawn by the charming play of Ajita's beauty,

analyzed: vyatanuta kṛpayā yaḥ tattva dīpam purāṇam
translated: Who, in the past, out of compassion, composed the Purana, a lamp of truth,🔽Attracting the essence of the swans with his charming pastimes, even though unconquered,

analyzed: tam akhila vṛjina ghnam vyāsa sūnum nataḥ smi
translated: I bow to that son of Vyasa, the destroyer of all sins.

analyzed: sūtaḥ uvāca
translated: Suta said:

original: yaṃ brahmā varuṇendrarudramarutaḥ stunvanti divyaiḥ stavair
analyzed: yam brahmā varuṇa indra rudra marutaḥ stunvanti divyaiḥ stavaiḥ
translated: Whom Brahma, Varuna, Indra, Rudra, and the Maruts praise with divine hymns,

analyzed: vedaiḥ sa aṅga padakrama upaniṣadaiḥ gāyanti yam sāmagāḥ
translated: Whom the Sama-singers sing about with the Vedas, with their limbs, words, and Upanishads,

analyzed: dhyāna avasthita tad gatena manasā paśyanti yam yoginaḥ
translated: Whom the yogis see with their minds fixed in meditation, absorbed in Him,

original: yasyāntaṃ na viduḥ surāsuragaṇā devāya tasmai namaḥ🔽pṛṣṭhe bhrāmyad amandamandaragirigrāvāgrakaṇḍūyanān
analyzed: yasya antam na viduḥ sura asura gaṇāḥ devāya tasmai namaḥ  pṛṣṭhe bhrāmyat amanda mandara giri grāvā agra kaṇḍūyanān
translated: To that God, whose end the hosts of gods and demons do not know, I offer salutations.🔽May the winds of the breath of the Lord, who has the form of a tortoise, protect you all,

original: nidrāloḥ kamaṭhākṛter bhagavataḥ śvāsānilāḥ pāntu vaḥ
analyzed: nidrāloḥ kamaṭha ākṛteḥ bhagavataḥ śvāsa anilāḥ pāntu vaḥ
translated: As they scratch the tip of the Mandara mountain, which is being whirled around on His back,

analyzed: yat saṃskāra kalā anuvartana vaśāt velā nibhena ambhasām
translated: By the power of following the subtle qualities of His creation, the ocean's ebb and flow

original: yātāyātam atandritaṃ jalanidher nādyāpi viśrāmyati🔽purāṇasaṅkhyāsambhūtim asya vācyaprayojane
analyzed: yāta āyātam atandritam jalanidheḥ na adya api viśrāmyati  purāṇa saṅkhyā sambhūtim asya vācya prayojane
translated: Has not ceased even today, with its water resembling the shoreline.🔽The enumeration of the Puranas, their origin, their subject matter and purpose,

original: dānaṃ dānasya māhātmyaṃ pāṭhādeś ca nibodhata
analyzed: dānam dānasya māhātmyam pāṭhādeḥ ca nibodhata
translated: The gift of the Puranas, the greatness of the gift, and the benefits of reciting them - listen.

original: brāhmaṃ daśa sahasrāṇi pādmaṃ pañconaṣaṣṭi ca
analyzed: brāhmam daśa sahasrāṇi pādmam pañconaṣaṣṭi ca
translated: The Brahma Purana has ten thousand verses, the Padma Purana has fifty-five thousand,

analyzed: śrīvaiṣṇavam trayoviṃśat caturviṃśati śaivakam
translated: The Śrīvaiṣṇava has twenty-three, the Śaiva twenty-four,

analyzed: daśa aṣṭau śrībhāgavatam nāradam pañcaviṃśati
translated: The Śrībhāgavata has eighteen, the Nārada twenty-five,

original: mārkaṇḍaṃ nava vāhnaṃ ca daśapañca catuḥśatam
analyzed: mārkaṇḍam nava vāhnam ca daśa pañca catuḥśatam
translated: The Mārkaṇḍa has nine, the Āgneya has fifteen, the Padma has four hundred,

original: caturdaśa bhaviṣyaṃ syāt tathā pañcaśatāni ca
analyzed: caturdaśa bhaviṣyam syāt tathā pañca śatāni ca
translated: The Bhaviṣya has fourteen, and likewise five hundred,

analyzed: daśa aṣṭau brahmavaivartam laiṅgam ekādaśa eva tu
translated: The Brahmavaivarta has eighteen, the Liṅga has eleven,

analyzed: caturviṃśati vārāham ekāśīti sahasrakam
translated: The Vārāha has twenty-four, and one hundred and eighty thousand,

original: skāndaṃ śataṃ tathā caikaṃ vāmanaṃ daśa kīrtitam
analyzed: skāndam śatam tathā ca ekam vāmanam daśa kīrtitam
translated: The Skanda has one hundred and one, the Vāmana is declared to be ten,

original: kaurmaṃ saptadaśākhyātaṃ mātsyaṃ tat tu caturdaśa
analyzed: kaurmam saptadaśa ākhyātam mātsyam tat tu caturdaśa
translated: The Kaurma is said to be seventeen, the Matsya has fourteen,

analyzed: ekonaviṃśat sauparṇam brahmāṇḍam dvādaśa eva tu
translated: The Saumya has nineteen, the Brāhmaṇḍa has twelve,

analyzed: evam purāṇa sandohaḥ catur lakṣaḥ udāhṛtaḥ
translated: Thus the collection of Purāṇas is said to be four hundred thousand.

analyzed: tatra aṣṭadaśa sāhasram śrībhāgavatam iṣyate
translated: Therein, the Śrībhāgavata is considered to be eighteen thousand.

original: idaṃ bhagavatā pūrvaṃ brahmaṇe nābhipaṅkaje🔽sthitāya bhavabhītāya kāruṇyāt samprakāśitam🔽ādimadhyāvasāneṣu vairāgyākhyānasaṃyutam
analyzed: idam bhagavatā pūrvam brahmaṇe nābhi paṅkaje  sthitāya bhava bhītāya kāruṇyāt samprakāśitam  ādi madhya avasāneṣu vairāgya ākhyāna saṃyutam
translated: This was formerly revealed by the Lord out of compassion to Brahmā,🔽who was abiding in the lotus of his navel and was afraid of worldly existence,🔽at the beginning, middle and end, along with stories of renunciation,
a series of stories of Lord Hari's pastimes, delighting the good and the gods.
The essence of all Vedanta is the non-dual Brahman, characterized by oneness with the Self,

original: vastv advitīyaṃ tanniṣṭhaṃ kaivalyaikaprayojanam🔽prauṣṭhapadyāṃ paurṇamāsyāṃ hemasiṃhasamanvitam
analyzed: prauṣṭhapadyām paurṇamāsyām hema siṃha samanvitam
translated: The reality without a second, which is the sole purpose of liberation.🔽One who gives the Bhagavata Purana, along with a golden lion, on the full moon day of the month of Proshthapada,

original: dadāti yo bhāgavataṃ sa yāti paramāṃ gatim
analyzed: dadāti yaḥ bhāgavatam sa yāti paramām gatim
translated: He attains the highest state.

original: rājante tāvad anyāni purāṇāni satāṃ gaṇe
analyzed: rājante tāvat anyāni purāṇāni satām gaṇe
translated: Other Puranas shine in the assembly of the virtuous

analyzed: yāvat bhāgavatam na eva śrūyate mṛta sāgaram
translated: Only as long as the Bhagavata, the ocean of nectar, is not heard.

analyzed: sarva vedānta sāram hi śrī bhāgavatam iṣyate
translated: The Shrimad Bhagavatam is considered to be the essence of all Vedanta.
One who is satisfied with the nectar of its rasa has no interest anywhere else.

original: nimnagānāṃ yathā gaṅgā devānām acyuto yathā
analyzed: nimnagānām yathā gaṅgā devānām acyutaḥ yathā
translated: Just as the Ganges is the best of all rivers, just as Achyuta is the best of all gods,

original: vaiṣṇavānāṃ yathā śambhuḥ purāṇānām idam tathā
analyzed: vaiṣṇavānām yathā śambhuḥ purāṇānām idam tathā
translated: Just as Shambhu is the best of all Vaishnavas, this Purana is the best of all Puranas.

original: kṣetrāṇāṃ caiva sarveṣāṃ yathā kāśī hy anuttamā
analyzed: kṣetrāṇām ca eva sarveṣām yathā kāśī hi anuttamā
translated: Just as Kashi is the best of all holy places,

analyzed: tathā purāṇa vrātānām śrīmat bhāgavatam dvijāḥ
translated: In the same way, O Brahmins, the Shrimad Bhagavatam is the best of all Puranas.

original: śrīmadbhāgavataṃ purāṇam amalaṃ yad vaiṣṇavānāṃ priyaṃ
analyzed: śrīmat bhāgavatam purāṇam amalam yat vaiṣṇavānām priyam
translated: The pure Shrimad Bhagavatam Purana, which is dear to the devotees of Vishnu,

original: yasmin pāramahaṃsyam ekam amalaṃ jñānaṃ paraṃ gīyate
analyzed: yasmin pāramahaṃsyam ekam amalam jñānam param gīyate
translated: In which the supreme, spotless knowledge of the paramahamsas is sung.

analyzed: tatra jñāna virāga bhakti sahitam naiṣkarmyam āviskṛtam
translated: There, the state of being free from action, accompanied by knowledge, detachment, and devotion, is revealed.

original: tac chṛṇvan supaṭhan vicāraṇaparo bhaktyā vimucyen naraḥ
analyzed: tat śṛṇvan su paṭhan vicāraṇa paraḥ bhaktyā vimucyet naraḥ
translated: A man, listening to it, reciting it well, intent on contemplation, with devotion, would be liberated.

original: kasmai yena vibhāsito 'yam atulo jñānapradīpaḥ purā
analyzed: kasmai yena vibhāsitaḥ yam atulaḥ jñāna pradīpaḥ purā
translated: To whom was this incomparable lamp of knowledge shown by him in the past?

original: tadrūpeṇa ca nāradāya munaye kṛṣṇāya tadrūpiṇā
analyzed: tad rūpeṇa ca nāradāya munaye kṛṣṇāya tad rūpiṇā
translated: To the sage Nārada, in that form, and to Kṛṣṇa, in that form,

analyzed: yogi indrāya tad ātma nātha bhagavat rātāya kāruṇyatas
translated: Out of compassion, to the lord of great yogis, to Viṣṇurāta,

original: tac chuddhaṃ vimalaṃ viśokam amṛtaṃ satyaṃ paraṃ dhīmahi
analyzed: tat śuddham vimalam viśokam amṛtam satyam param dhīmahi
translated: We meditate on that pure, spotless, sorrowless, immortal, supreme truth.

analyzed: namaḥ tasmai bhagavate vāsudevāya sākṣiṇe
translated: Salutations to that Lord Vāsudeva, the witness,

original: ya idam kṛpayā kasmai vyācacakṣe mumukṣave
analyzed: yaḥ idam kṛpayā kasmai vyācacakṣe mumukṣave
translated: By whom this was explained out of compassion to someone desiring liberation.

analyzed: yogi indrāya namaḥ tasmai śukāya brahma rūpiṇe
translated: Salutations to that lord of great yogis, to Śuka, who has the form of Brahman,

analyzed: saṃsāra sarpa daṣṭam yaḥ viṣṇurātam amūmucat
translated: By whom Viṣṇurāta, bitten by the snake of worldly existence, was liberated.

original: bhave bhave yathā bhaktiḥ pādayos tava jāyate
analyzed: bhave bhave yathā bhaktiḥ pādayoḥ tava jāyate
translated: May devotion to Your feet arise in every birth.

original: tathā kuruṣva deveśa nāthas tvaṃ no yataḥ prabho
analyzed: tathā kuruṣva deveśa nāthaḥ tvam naḥ yatas prabho
translated: Do so, O Lord of gods, for You are our protector, O Lord.

analyzed: nāma saṅkīrtanam yasya sarva pāpa praṇāśanam
translated: The mere utterance of whose name destroys all sins,

original: praṇāmo duḥkhaśamanas taṃ namāmi hariṃ param
analyzed: praṇāmaḥ duḥkha śamanaḥ tam namāmi harim param
translated: I bow to that supreme Hari, whose salutation removes all sorrows.
